segments.text: After the pledges for Speaker were pretty well secured for Mr. Clayton, and everyone was resigned to the fact that he would be elected Speaker in January of 1975 when the legislature convened, I was in the Capitol, two people that

associated with education stopped me to congratulate me on the fact that I was going to be appointed chairman of the Education Committee when the legislature convened and the Speaker made his appointments.
I had served on the Education Committee in the previous session and then served on the Education Committee during the Constitutional Convention.
the second person had told me this, I immediately proceeded to Mr. Clayton's office and spoke to him for the first time since day blitz.
I told him of the rumor that I had heard in the Capitol, and I wanted him to understand that
I would rather serve on the Appropriations Committee than be chairman of the Education Committee.
Of course, I did not get a commitment from Speaker-elect Clayton at that time and did not expect to.
Shortly thereafter, I run into one of his early supporters.
In our discussions,
He indicated to me that he had an interest in education and would like to serve on that committee or to chair the committee.
I asked him if he had shared that with Mr. Clayton, and he said no, they had not talked about it.
I suggested to him that he should do that and do it very soon.
That was a turning point or not, I do not know.
and was appointed Chairman of the Education Committee.
After our meetings I began to think about my appointments and I thought maybe I will be appointed as Vice Chairman of the House Appropriations Committee since I was an early supporter.
Never occurred to me that I might have a shot at being Chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.
I did not to say any more to the speaker about it and leave it in his hands as to what the appointment might be.
That committee appointments were being discussed in his office on a daily basis.
A constant source of conversation once the legislature convened in January and
He was elected and committee appointments were still pending.

It wasn't until the night before the committee assignments were announced that the speaker pulled me aside at a reception and told me that he was appointing me chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, that he had been under extreme pressure
to name the person who had turned the tide in the speaker's race, but he just was not going to make that appointment.
He did admonish me that I'd give A&M everything they wanted, but between the two of us, we'd take care of A&M.
I told him he could always trust me to do what was right.
Later there was not only a great deal of discussion about who would chair the Appropriations Committee, but probably more discussion about who would be the vice chairman.
Baker at one point wanted to name the former chairman of the House Appropriations Committee as my vice chairman.
Fortunately for me,
he was talked out of that and said that it would not be fair to me as chairman to have a former chairman serving as my vice chairman.
I did serve on the committee, but not as vice chairman.
That first session in 1975 that I served as chairman of the Appropriations Committee was a very challenging one and a
bigger tasks than I had imagined.
Working under the new rules and in the open, the agencies of the state had become much more aggressive.
Numerous members of the committee that had more seniority than I had in the serving in the legislature.
Number five,
chairman of major committees that served on the Appropriations Committee with me.
The first major challenge that I faced from Fred Head, who had helped the Speaker get elected by throwing his support behind him,
Prior to Labor Day, the named chairman of the Higher Education Committee, after his campaign to become chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, had fell short.
In addition, he was a member of the House Appropriations Committee.
As chairman of the Higher Education Committee, he had put together a proposal for funding higher education that
was a severe attack on the Permanent University Fund.

He had taken Permanent University Fund proceeds and appropriated for operations at Texas A&M University, which gutted the excellence fund that Texas A&M and the University of Texas had enjoyed over the years.
Once I saw what Mr. Head was doing with his proposal, I decided that I had to pick an issue that I could beat him on.
His proposal, he had refused to use updated enrollments because this would take another $17 million in general revenue funds to fund the updated enrollments.
Mr. Head laid out his proposal.
I asked if he had used updated enrollments.
He said he had not.
I immediately moved to use updated enrollments.
He vehemently opposed it, saying that it was going to cost us $17 million more to do so.
And we took a vote, and he was resoundingly defeated.

I then announced that the was adjourned pending the arrival of officials from the Texas A&M system and the University of Texas system who would appear before the Appropriations Committee to give testimony with regards to the use of the permanent university fund.
We had not
had a relation of the use of those proceeds and that Mr. Head was attempting to fund those without the committee having any knowledge of how those funds were being expended.

The next day, the House Appropriations Committee convened with the chairman of the board of the University of Texas System, the former governor, Alan Shivers, and Jack Williams, chancellor of the Texas A&M University System, appearing before the committee explaining how the proceeds of the permanent university fund were being expended at the two institutions.
Once those explanations were given,
had little problem in rejecting Mr. Head's proposal that those funds be used for normal operations at Texas A&M and University of Texas.
One of the lessons I learned in chairing the House Appropriations Committee that first year was the little attention sometimes that is paid to riders that are placed in the appropriations bill.
The new rider placed in the bill by a House member that provided that a person who accrued sick leave when they left employment with the state could receive a payment for that sick leave.

I was concerned about the rider when it went in, but decided that we could handle it in conference committee and was hopeful that the Senate would object to the rider and insist that it be taken out of the bill.
Instead, little attention was given to it and the rider stayed in the bill.
And as a result, many of the small agencies had difficulty in raising funds to pay for sick leave when some of their employees retired or left office.
Not a workable provision because most agencies do not keep accurate records regarding sick leave days of the executive officials.
they were getting paid for all of the sick leave days that they had accrued with very few sick leave days taken off.
Another rider that became a problem and I had hoped would be overlooked was one that authorized Texas A&M University to cooperate with the South Texas
College of Law with affiliation agreements.

I was approached on a one-on-one basis by a senator on the conference committee who had asked me to support the rider and I agreed to if he would talk to the Speaker of the House and get his agreement.
The speaker agreed.
I showed the rider to my conferees, and of course they acceded to my wishes and said whatever I wanted to do.
So the rider was placed in the appropriations bill at the conference committee level.
Under the new rules of the House, any new language had to be placed on a resolution and passed in the House and the Senate.
The Senate passes these resolutions, still to this day, passes the resolutions with little debate.
The House might have done the same thing with regards to this particular provision, but in the process of putting it in the bill, one of the legislators overheard what we were doing
and reported it to his legislator boss.
When the resolution was presented, which is a rather thick document that shows all the changes in the bill, this one item was flagged for discussion.
They had given very little thought to the rider and did not know exactly what it did.
I knew that it did not create a law school, but there was no convincing the members of the legislature that it wasn't the first step to creating a law school.
And a vote was taken and the provision was stricken.
During the legislative session in 1975, Robert Preston, a half-brother, died suddenly of a heart attack.
Robert was about ready to retire from Humble Oil and Refining Company in Baytown when this occurred.
Father's first wife was Della Edge Presnell, and Robert was an offspring of that marriage.
She died shortly after Robert's birth.
My father subsequently married my mother.
Della Edge Presnell was a twin sister to Ella Benbow.
whose husband, Tom, ran a grocery store in Bryan.
And Robert stayed with the Benbos much of the time as a young man.
Thought of Aunt Ella and Uncle Tom Benbo as members of the family.
All of us personal boys.
September of 1975, shortly after that
After the legislative session, my father died at the age of 83.
He has a distinction of being the only man in Brazos County to have two sons serve in the legislature.
There have only been two or three sets of brothers, to my knowledge, that have served in the legislature.
I don't know the numbers, but there have been very few.
My father always enjoyed politics and I think he enjoyed campaigning, that first campaign that I had in 1968.
I'm glad that he lived to see me serve in a leadership position in the legislature before his death.
I also lived to see the family farm that I operated

and still operate under the family land heritage program of the department of agriculture requires the same family to operate the farm for over a hundred years my farm is part of the twenty three hundred and ten acres that great grandfather robert hutchpeth had acquired in eighteen sixty six nineteen seventy six
the Texas Public Employees Association came to me and asked me to carry legislation that would provide that the state pay the employee portion of the Social Security tax.
They had discussed this matter with former Secretary of Labor Marshall, who was a member of the University of Texas faculty,
And he had assured them that this would be tax-free money to the employee by the state paying the employee's portion.
Produced the bill in the House along with Senator Doggett introducing a companion bill, Senate Bill 20, in the Senate.
With the bill passed, we had to make some concessions.
we had to cap the payment at the then current rate of 5.85% and at the current level of $16,500 that the state would pay.
When we passed the bill, we still did not know whether or not these funds would be tax-free to the employee.
out later that they were not tax-free and very little advantage was received by the employees being paid this way.
Fortunately, it took a long time to get the statute off the books because of the mechanics of backing out the payment in a fair and equitable way to the state employees.
finally repealed in the mid-1990s.
The issue that we spent a great deal of time trying to resolve was how to control off-campus programs within our community college system.
Voices were being taught in various locations
The state was having to pick up the tab, yet there was no control of the quality of these programs, and there were certainly a lot of questions regarding the standards that existed in a lot of them.
Leadership positions of speaker, lieutenant governor, and governor did not change in 1977.
We still had Bill Clayton as speaker,
Bill Hobby as Lieutenant Governor and Dolph Briscoe as Governor, did see a rather dramatic change in the makeup of the membership of the House Appropriations Committee.
The Speaker had decided that Chairman of the Committee would not serve concurrently on the Appropriations Committee.
It's created a lot of vacancies, which he was more than happy to fill with people that wanted to serve on the Appropriations Committee.
Because of these changes, I ended up with a majority of big spenders, lost control and committee of any ability to write a bill that would
viable should it be sent directly to the comptroller.
I rationalized to myself that this was not a problem, that I would have control in the conference committee and we could make the bill certify at that point.
The problem that I ran into was that once we got the bill to the floor of the House, I had very little support for its passage.
So we had to come up with some creative way to gain support of the bill and get it passed and over to the Senate and then to a conference committee.
Had I known we would have the problems we had on the floor, I would have probably taken some positive action to reduce the total amount of the bill
in committee just so that we could get the bill passed in the House and in a conference committee.
The first three days we debated a bill making no progress in reducing the size of the bill which would be necessary to get the votes that we needed to pass it.
On the evening of the third day,
As I was preparing to get some rest alone in my apartment in the old Stephen F. Austin Hotel, when I heard this voice say, the author has the right to perfect his own bill.
I put my head on my pillow.
I realized that was the answer.
that I had to offer perfecting amendments as the author of the bill to reduce the amount to a level that would be acceptable to the majority of the legislators.
The next morning, I arrived at the Capitol early and directed staff to amend the bill
back to the level that was approved originally by the Legislative Budget Board.
In other words, cut out everything that the committee had put in the bill.
We'd have to add some of it back in, but I thought we could get reductions that way.
My first estimate was that we'd get about $200 million out of the bill and hope that that would get us the votes that we needed.
As it turned out, we cut about $400 million out of the bill on the floor of the House through the author's perfecting amendments.
This was unpopular and unprecedented and caused a lot of unrest, but it did get the bill approved.
out of the house and into conference committee where we were able to make the necessary changes.
I thought I had met head on one of the most difficult challenges that I had ever faced.
Unfortunately, Texas Monthly did not view it that way.
They came out with their list of the worst 10.
My name was on it.
The speaker assured me that in the future I would have more members that would support me on the Appropriations Committee.
Depending upon the issue, about five votes out of the 21 is all that I had during that entire session.

Later that year, during the interim, the Speaker had asked a friend of mine and I to travel to Olympia, Washington to review the interactive budget monitoring system that had been put in at the State Capitol in Olympia.
The Capitol had hired a number of former Boeing
aircraft employees that had intimate knowledge of how systems could be devised to provide support to the legislature with regards to budgetary matters.
We were quite impressed with the system and came back to the Legislative Budget Board
and proposed a feasibility study by Coopers and Libran to determine what it would take to put in a system in Texas.
Things that would be required would be a uniform system of accounting, which Texas did not have within state government.
And we realized that this would be required.
The prison librarian did the study, and for a while that was, we thought, the end of it.
Surprisingly, we found out that they were continuing to work and had ran up a $300,000 bill that they presented to us without the legislature or the speaker or the lieutenant governor
or anyone authorizing such an expenditure.
I urged them that they should not be doing this, that we had no authorization to proceed.
The program was never approved and probably should not have been.
And the principles that authorized this work and by the Cooper's and Librand organization, I understand, were later fired.
We did have in 1979 or 81 had a resolution that would allow Cooper's and Librand to sue the state of Texas for their
money that they had expended on this project.
Of course, the legislature did not approve a resolution to sue itself, to allow itself to be sued, I mean, and so Coopers and Libran remains unpaid.
In 1979, Bill Clayton continued to serve as Speaker and Bill Hobby as Lieutenant Governor, and we had the election of the first
Republican governor in 100 years.
Bill Clements was elected governor.
Inflation rampant.
It was necessary or prudent to give the state employees a pay raise.
Do it on an emergency basis so that we could start catching up on where we had fallen behind.
Senator Lloyd Doggett, a liberal Democrat, introduced the bill in the Senate at 6.8%.
At that time, Governor Clements had given the bill to a freshman state representative in the House for introduction there.
The Senate quickly passed its bill and sent it over to the House.
I, in turn, asked the freshman House member to pick up the Senate bill, but that we would hold a hearing on his bill as well.
Understood the protocol that the bill that passed first would be the one that would be used as a vehicle.
Hearing was held, but before we reported the bill out of committee with any amendments,
A conference was held in the governor's office, and agreement was reached that we would reduce the increase to state employees from 6.8% to 5.1%.
There was a great deal of publicity given to the reduction that was made, and even though the leadership was all in concurrence,
their mention ever made by this by the press.
Two significant appropriations in the 1979 session, as far as Texas A&M University's system is concerned, was an appropriation to the vet clinic for its operations.
In the past, the vet clinic was expected to be self-supporting and not receive any general revenue monies to operate the clinic.
It was also the session that the purchase money for purchasing the Herman Professional Building in Houston for the Prairie View Nursing Program was provided.
was always difficult to make decisions regarding private buildings for state use or to construct new buildings.
Legislature just does not have a good handle on doing these kinds of things.
How do you decide on a building in one part of the state versus a building in another part of the state?
These are decisions that should be made at some other level rather than at the legislature level.
Where in 1980 it was proposed that there be an appreciation dinner at the Brazos Center
to make a show of support and raise some funds for my reelection campaign later that year, should there be one.
My supporters decided that it should be a fish fry.
Sounded like a great idea.
The only problem is it turned out to be the coldest night of the year, and the fish would not thaw.
When the fish that was frozen hit the grease, it would cool it down so fast that we could not buy fish fast enough for the crowd that we had that evening.

the people that stayed at home and watched the appreciation dinner or saw the appreciation dinner on TV thought we had a huge overflow crowd because people were standing in line waiting to get their fish.
The TV viewing audience did not know was that we couldn't get the fish to fry fast enough.
I did file for reelection in 1980 in opposition.
There were several major issues that faced the legislature in 1981.
Bill had Bill Clayton as Speaker, Bill Hobby as Lieutenant Governor, and Bill Clements as Governor.
The issue at the end of each decade is legislative redistricting.
This indicated that Brazos County now represented a perfect district, population-wise.
At first glance, one would think this would make it quite simple, but having a county with the exact population required for a legislative district
does create problems.
It removes flexibility that the writers of the redistricting bill would like to have in working with districts that surround the county with the right population.
I know Brazos County was the only county that had such a population.
The fact of Brazos County having a perfect population meant that two incumbent colleagues in the legislature just west of Brazos County ended up being paired.
And the legislator to the east had some difficulty in getting the kind of district that he wanted.
In the 1981 session, we once again met the challenge of constitutional amendment to the permanent university fund.
There was an effort to rewrite the higher education portion of the constitution to deal primarily with the issue of how the schools outside of the permanent university fund are provided
their construction funding.
They had been using the 10 cent tax, i.e.
10 cents on a $100 valuation, to generate the revenues used by schools outside of the permanent university fund.
There was a challenge to this fund as being unconstitutional, and it was one that we were likely to lose in the courts, thereby leaving these schools with no source of funds.
Amendments are required to get 100 votes.
An amendment to the proposal was offered to put Prairie View into the Permanent University Fund for 1-6.
I felt like this was not in our best interest since Prairie View was actually over-built at the time and A&M was under-built.
And to put a formula in the Constitution did not sense.
I was defeated with regards to the amendment since it took only a majority vote.
But I was able to garner enough votes in opposition
to the amendment to keep it from getting the necessary 100 votes required to pass.
That brought a call from Governor Clements to meet in his office and discuss the issue.
Governor Clements proceeded to advise me that Prairie View had not been treated fairly and started giving examples of construction items that had not been funded at Prairie View.

I proceeded to point out to Governor Clements that all of the construction items that he had mentioned were items that only the legislature could provide the funds and not the A&M System Board of Regents.
It is difficult to win an argument with the governor and particularly Governor Clements,
I think I was able to persuade him that we were not going to give in on the issue and that there had to be some other resolution.
The session adjourned without addressing the question of education funding in the Constitution.
The issues that I have dealt with
during my legislative years, the one that I caught the most flack from my colleagues was the one dealing with the teacher retirement system.
Prior to the session in 1981, I had asked the Legislative Budget Board to consider what the ramifications would be if we passed a statute
that required the teacher's retirement system to implement the rule of 85.
The rule of 85 being that if your years toward retirement and your age totaled to be 85, you could draw full retirement.
This was the system that was used in the state employee's retirement system, and I had had requests for this to be applied to the teacher retirement system.
I quickly learned that the Legislative Budget Board did not get very good information from the teacher retirement system, and this had been a real problem.
This request of mine gave them the impetus to seek information from outside sources regarding the viability of the teacher retirement system.
The result of the study the Legislative Budget Board made, it was determined that the teacher retirement system could
use their requirement for general revenue appropriations by $217 million and still be the most viable retirement system in the nation.
The budget board met just prior to the legislative session.
It was decided to go ahead and expend those funds through the appropriations process
on the assumption that a bill would be passed that would reduce the money flowing into the teacher's retirement system by $217 million.
I had made all kinds of compromises with the teacher retirement system to get the bill passed.
The Retired Teachers Association, they continued to hammer away
on their own legislators to the point it was extremely difficult to get the bill passed.
Members that supported me on the issue to get it passed apparently heard from their retirees into the teacher retirement system for years to come.
Ross Perot was heading up a program called War on Drugs.
This was to get some bills passed in the legislature that would help curb the drug traffic in Texas.
I met with Mr. Perot prior to the session in College Station here and was supportive of what he was trying to do.
He had asked me to carry several of the bills, but I declined on a basis that, as chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, I just did not have the time to carry additional bills.
But I would help in every way that I could to see that, to help get the bills passed through the legislature.
I asked him to take to a friend of mine
And I told this friend I would help him with it.
It was a bill that required a triplicate prescription of all drugs that were considered dangerous.
I had a bill in the Appropriations Committee to make Martin Luther King's birthday a holiday.
The members of the committee were not supportive at all of this bill, and I knew that the votes were not there.
I did want to do something with regards to holidays because it had been something somewhat controversial.
I kept telling the author of the Martin Luther King birthday bill that I...

was working on something and that i would uh... give him a hearing at the time i got the other bill worked up and i found out that he was uh... not letting the triplicate prescription bill come out of his committee even though the votes in the committee were there the triplicate prescription bill uh... was a concept that would hopefully reduce
dangerous drugs by a considerable amount.
Finally, the author of the bill brought the speaker to my desk and said, we want to get the bill out of committee.
And I said, fine, I'll give you a hearing on your bill if you'll pass out the triplicate prescription bill.
His reaction was, no way.
that lasted about ten seconds, and he came back and said, okay, it's a deal.
So I attempted to get his bill out once he had passed the triplicate prescription bill out, and of course I could not get the bill, necessary votes to pass the bill.
Understand that the triplicate prescription bill has reduced drug trafficking by a significant amount.
1981 was one of the first years we had to deal with teachers' pay in the Appropriations Committee.
We're falling behind in their pay because of the high rate of inflation and the fact that teachers have always been underpaid.
One thing that I wanted to avoid was the bill
more funds than the comptroller could certify.
The member who was handling the education portion of the appropriations bill made a proposal to
provide a 28.5% increase for school teachers.
I knew what the fiscal implications were and did not support his proposal.
Consequently, it was killed.
The speaker immediately contacted me and said that was his proposal and
He wanted it brought up.
I said, we don't have the money.
He said, I've got the money for you.
I said, okay, if you assure me we've got the money for you, I'll find a way to bring it back up and we'll get it passed.
So after a few hours, it passed.
